agent_action: used bg for CLI name
corrected_action: use floop for CLI name

agent_action: Added .floop/ to .gitignore treating it as runtime data
corrected_action: .floop/ contains project data (corrections, behaviors) that should be version controlled, similar to .beads/

agent_action: Put lengthy tool-specific documentation (like bv sidecar) directly in AGENTS.md
corrected_action: Keep AGENTS.md focused on project workflow; move detailed tool docs to separate files (e.g., docs/BV_SIDECAR.md) and link from AGENTS.md

agent_action: Claimed Phase 1 complete based on reading code
corrected_action: Actually run the tools, test edge cases, dogfood before claiming done

agent_action: Declared work complete based on reading code and running minimal tests
corrected_action: Validate thoroughly: run full end-to-end workflows, test error cases, actually use the tool (dogfood), and be honest about gaps between 'works for now' vs 'properly done'

agent_action: Spawned parallel sub-agents working directly in the same worktree, risking file conflicts and uncommitted change contamination
corrected_action: Use git worktrees to give each parallel agent an isolated checkout on its own branch, then merge via PRs or cherry-picks

agent_action: used pip
corrected_action: use uv instead

agent_action: committed to main
corrected_action: never commit directly to main branch

agent_action: Only considered project-local behavior storage
corrected_action: Consider both global (~/.floop/) and local (./.floop/) scopes - users want personal preferences across ALL projects AND project-specific conventions

agent_action: Waited for explicit user instruction to use floop
corrected_action: Agents should proactively use floop during conversations - capture corrections in real-time using own judgment and intuition

agent_action: Assumed one storage location would be enough
corrected_action: Global scope is for agent's personal preferences/style across ALL work. Local scope is for team/project-specific conventions. Both have distinct value.

agent_action: Created inline usage instructions in AGENTS.md
corrected_action: Create a dedicated usage guide (docs/FLOOP_USAGE.md) and reference it prominently in AGENTS.md - separates 'what' from 'how' and makes instructions comprehensive

agent_action: Assumed agents would know when to use tools based on general context
corrected_action: Create explicit hooks in AGENTS.md that mandate tool usage - use WARNING/CRITICAL markers and 'READ FIRST' to ensure visibility

agent_action: Jumped directly into implementation after planning without creating beads structure
corrected_action: Always create detailed beads (epic + tasks) with dependency graphs after planning - enables easy handoff between agents and sessions

agent_action: Created plan but didn't structure work into beads with dependencies
corrected_action: After planning, immediately create epic + tasks with --parent and --deps flags to establish dependency graph - makes work parallelizable and agent-handoff friendly

agent_action: Assumed same agent should continue from planning through implementation
corrected_action: Plan with one agent, create beads, then hand off to fresh agent for implementation - keeps context clean and allows specialization

agent_action: Committed beads export state changes in a loop, causing infinite commits
corrected_action: Beads export state auto-updates with each commit hash. After final push, restore the export state file instead of committing it again to break the cycle.

agent_action: Waited for permission to use tools
corrected_action: Proactively use floop to capture corrections in real-time without asking

agent_action: Test error handling
corrected_action: Always test both success and error paths

agent_action: Made changes specific to feedback-loop project
corrected_action: This is a project-specific behavior for testing

agent_action: Only saved to one store
corrected_action: Use scope=both to save important learnings to both local and global

agent_action: test
corrected_action: test

agent_action: Waited for explicit instruction or permission before using development tools and capturing learnings
corrected_action: Proactively use available tools (floop, beads, etc.) during conversations - capture corrections and learnings in real-time using own judgment without asking permission

agent_action: Committed beads export-state changes repeatedly, creating infinite commit loop
corrected_action: Beads export-state auto-updates with each commit hash. After final push, restore the export-state file (git restore) instead of committing it again to break the cycle

agent_action: Created vague tasks without dependency information or clear structure
corrected_action: Always create detailed beads (epic + tasks) with dependency graphs after planning - enables easy handoff between agents and sessions. Use descriptive titles, clear acceptance criteria, and explicit blockers

agent_action: Didn't create structured task breakdown
corrected_action: After planning, create detailed beads with epic + tasks, dependency graphs, clear acceptance criteria, and explicit blockers for easy handoff

agent_action: Test save to global
corrected_action: This should save to global store

agent_action: test proactive use
corrected_action: Proactively use tools without asking

agent_action: test
corrected_action: this is a test

agent_action: Waited for permission before using development tools
corrected_action: Proactively use development tools (floop, beads, etc.) during all conversations - capture corrections in real-time without asking permission

agent_action: Created vague task breakdowns
corrected_action: After planning, create detailed beads (epic + tasks) with dependency graphs, clear acceptance criteria, and explicit blockers for easy agent handoff

agent_action: Waited for permission
corrected_action: Proactively use tools without asking

agent_action: Created verbose file-based handoff with extensive details, assuming next agent needs complete context documented
corrected_action: Keep handoffs concise and conversational - next agent will investigate themselves. Avoid files that could get committed to git. Focus on: what's done, what's next, quick start commands.
